p: Following initial work demonstrating that ASICs are activated by extracellular protons, much research has been dedicated to identifying the region and amino acids that detect protons [ 27]. In the very first crystal structure of cASIC1a, an acidic pocket situated between the finger-thumb-ball region, was proposed to be critical for proton sensing [ 12]. However, mutagenesis of residues within this acidic pocket did not fully abolish proton sensitivity for ASIC1a [ 29, 30]. Additionally, rASIC2a is proton-sensitive, whereas its splice variant rASIC2b is not, yet both subunits contain the same 5/6 carboxylate residues of the acidic pocket; site-directed mutagenesis and chimera construction of rASIC2a/2b have identified that the first 87 amino acids after transmembrane domain 1 are of particular importance [ 16, 31]. Furthermore, mutational analysis of the rASIC1a palm domain has identified it to also be an influential component to proton activation, but of less importance than the finger-thumb-ball acidic pocket region [ 32, 33].
